header.title: Studies on Astral Magic in Medieval Jewish Thought
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Jewish Studies, Medieval Philosophy

central_thesis: This book comprehensively analyzes the integration, legitimation, and evolution of astral magic within medieval Jewish intellectual discourse, particularly among philosophers and kabbalists from the 12th century until the Spanish expulsion. It demonstrates how astral magic, often perceived as a 'science' or 'ancient wisdom,' was adopted, adapted, and debated, becoming a significant factor in theological explanations of biblical commandments and events, despite its problematic proximity to idolatry and Maimonides' fervent critique.

structure_content.summary: Defines astral magic as the utilization of celestial emanations (råhaniyy§t) for practical purposes through specific preparations (effigies, amulets). It traces the origins of systematic astral magic to Hermetic literature and contextualizes its emergence within medieval Jewish thought as a theological and philosophical concern, leading to its adoption and subsequent intellectual debates, particularly in Spain and Provence.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter One - Judah Halevi and Abraham Ibn Ezra
structure_content.summary: Explores how Judah Halevi, using an esoteric style, presented Judaism as an 'alternative science' incorporating astral magic principles to explain commandments and prophecy, often equating their effect with drawing down spirituality. It details Abraham Ibn Ezra's view of astrology and astral magic as crucial to Jewish theology, his concept of 'supreme power,' and his method of concealing magic-astral interpretations within biblical exegesis due to concerns about idolatry while acknowledging their reality.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter Two - Magic, Experiential Science, and Scientific Method in Maimonides
structure_content.summary: Analyzes Maimonides' critical stance on magic, distinguishing between 'primitive' (folk) and 'learned' (astral) magic. Maimonides rejected astral magic as baseless idolatry and unscientific, contrasting it with 'segullot' (special properties) which, though unexplainable by Aristotelian causality, could be empirically verified. The chapter highlights the Maimonidean controversy and subsequent attempts to harmonize his views with the perceived efficacy of astral magic.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter Three - From Theurgy to Magic: Sacrifice in the Circle of Nahmanides and his Interpreters
structure_content.summary: Examines Nahmanides' synthesis of kabbalistic theurgy and astral magic in explaining sacrifices. He viewed sacrifices as a means to achieve cosmic balance (theurgy) and attract divine/astral emanation for material benefits (magic-astral, e.g., ransom for the scapegoat). The chapter traces how his disciples (e.g., Rashba, Ritba, Isaac of Acre, Bahya b. Asher) further developed these dual models, sometimes emphasizing the theurgic aspect or implicitly preserving the magic-astral dimension.

Documents the institutionalization of astral magic as a theological doctrine within 14th-century Spanish Jewish thought. Thinkers like Solomon Alconstantin, Samuel ibn Zarza, and Joseph Bonfils explicitly recognized pagan astral magic as a 'real science' and 'ancient wisdom,' reinterpreting biblical narratives (terafim, golden calf, brass serpent, Tabernacle) through magic-astral exegesis, even connecting demons to stellar forces and ritual acts to specific stellar influences.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter Five - The Controversy in Provence
structure_content.summary: Details the Provençal debate over astral magic, highlighting four distinct positions: absolute rejection (moderate rationalists like Meiri/Kokhavi), dubious but forbidden (traditionalists like Abba Mari, recognizing some efficacy but prohibiting it), psychologically effective but forbidden (Gersonides/Jedaiah ha-Penini), and true/permitted (Levi b. Abraham). Levi b. Abraham's radical legitimation of astral magic for medical and religious purposes, often reinterpreting Maimonides, is particularly emphasized.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter Six - The Controversy in Spanish Jewry
structure_content.summary: Focuses on the supercommentaries of Abraham Ibn Ezra, especially the intense dispute between Solomon Franco and Abraham Altabib. Franco openly advocated a comprehensive astral-magic theology, integrating planetary worship into interpretations of Torah precepts like the scapegoat ritual and dietary laws. Altabib fiercely opposed this, arguing for God's direct intervention and rejecting astral worship as idolatry, revealing the core theological contention over the autonomy of astral influence versus divine omnipotence.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter Seven - Jewish Rationalism In Late Medieval Byzantium
structure_content.summary: Examines the unique character of Byzantine Jewish rationalism, marked by intellectual remoteness, limited philosophical sources, and syncretism. It describes how figures like Elnathan b. Moses Kalkish, Judah Moskoni, and Ephraim ben Gershon admired Spanish rationalists while developing varied stances on astral magic, often rejecting popular magic while accepting a 'scientific' understanding of astral influences and esotericism, but within a more cautious Byzantine context.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter Eight - Magic, Astrology, and Theology in Late Medieval Byzantium
structure_content.summary: Delves into specific Byzantine approaches to astral magic. Kalkish viewed it as a 'special, great science' enabling healing and wonder-working, linking it to the 'magic of the name.' Moskoni offered a harmonistic synthesis of Maimonides' and Nahmanides' views on the scapegoat ritual's purpose. Comtino unequivocally rejected astral magic as idolatry and denied its efficacy, defining it as a 'craft.' Ephraim ben Gershon integrated kabbalistic and magic-astral elements into a theurgic model for drawing down divine abundance.

structure_content.chapter_title: Epilogue - Astral Magic and the Philosophy of Science
structure_content.summary: Reflects on the coexistence of Aristotelian and non-Aristotelian (occult, magical) scientific traditions in medieval Jewish thought, often with the latter concealed due to intellectual disapproval. It discusses the historiographical debate (Yates vs. Vickers) on magic's role in the rise of modern science, arguing that Jewish medieval magic was often practical (e.g., healing) and deeply integrated into theological explanations, presented with a garb of antiquity and mystery, necessitating a reevaluation of Jewish intellectual history.

key_concepts.definition: A specific kind of magic widespread among Jewish intellectuals that is predicated on the assumption that individuals can utilize celestial elements (stars, planets, constellations) and their constant emanations (råhaniyy§t) for their benefit and advantage, often involving the creation of images, effigies, or amulets at astrologically opportune times.

Celestial emanation from stars and signs, endowed with extraordinary forces, which can be absorbed and directed in the terrestrial world through suitable preparations. It is a key concept in astral magic and often linked to divine or sefirotic influence.

The practical process by which a magician absorbs and directs celestial emanations or supreme forces into the terrestrial world for specific purposes, such as healing, predicting the future, or changing natural forces, facilitated by ritual preparations.

Physical objects (e.g., made of plants, stones, spices, metals, animal parts) created or procured at a specific astrological time, symbolizing the emanating celestial source (planet or constellation), often with an engraved symbol, used to attract and absorb stellar influences.

The underlying philosophical principle, developed in Greek and Roman culture (e.g., Stoicism), that posits a sympathetic interaction between heaven and earth, and between symbolic representations and what they symbolize, forming the basis for astrology and astral magic.

A kabbalistic model where religious precepts (e.g., sacrificial rites) are performed with the intention of achieving proper balance, enhancing power and fertility within the divine world of the sefirot, and drawing down emanation for 'the need of heaven,' without primarily focusing on personal material benefit.

Hidden properties or inherent forces in existing objects (e.g., medicinal herbs, magnets) that produce efficacious results but cannot be explained by Aristotelian causality. Their efficacy is known only through 'experience' (experimenta) and Maimonides distinguished them from astral magic by their lack of astrological association and empirical verifiability.

A crucial notion in Abraham Ibn Ezra's astral magical outlook, referring to the influence emanating from the celestial bodies (planets, heavenly hosts) that can be drawn down. This power is seen to affect the material world and can be harnessed for various purposes.

A literary strategy involving enigmatic language, hints, and deliberate ambiguities used by authors (e.g., Judah Halevi, Abraham Ibn Ezra) when discussing sensitive or potentially controversial topics like astral magic, often to avoid accusations of idolatry or to present complex ideas to a select, initiated audience ('the wise').

The worship of stars, planets, or images, explicitly forbidden in Judaism. Astral magic often bordered on or was equated with idolatry, leading to debates among Jewish thinkers regarding its permissibility and whether true intention could differentiate it from forbidden practices.

A term used by Abraham Ibn Ezra to refer to the craft of making images (effigies) related to celestial bodies. This practice was often prohibited due to its resemblance to idolatry, yet Ibn Ezra implied an underlying astral-magical meaning to certain biblical injunctions against image-making.

Images, often human-shaped or designed as astronomical instruments (like astrolabes), believed in medieval Jewish thought to be capable of drawing down stellar spirituality for purposes such as divination or revealing hidden information. Their nature and legitimacy were a subject of extensive interpretation and debate.

A concept, particularly in Nahmanides' interpretation of sacrifices (e.g., the scapegoat), where an offering or ritual act is intended to divert or neutralize negative astral influences or divine wrath from an individual or community by channeling it to a designated object or animal.

practical_system.description: The book *describes* historical systems of astral magic as understood and practiced (or theorized about) by medieval Jewish thinkers, rather than providing a direct manual for practical application. It elucidates the underlying philosophy, reported techniques, and debates surrounding the operative side of these practices, demonstrating how they were conceptualized as means to draw down celestial or divine influence for various purposes.
tools: Images, effigies, amulets made of various materials (plants, stones, spices, gold, silver, copper, dough, wax), often shaped to represent celestial bodies or human forms (terafim).
Astrolabes and other astronomical instruments for determining precise stellar configurations and timing.
Incense for fumigation and attracting celestial influences.
Sacrifices of specific animals (goats, bullocks, rams) or birds.
Divine names and magic names, used in invocations or engraved on talismans.
Tabernacle, Temple, and their vessels (cherubim, candelabrum, altar, ephod, breastplate, Urim and Thummim) reinterpreted as talismans or conduits for supernal and astral power.
rituals: Creation or procurement of specific images, effigies, or amulets at astrologically auspicious times, symbolizing a planet or constellation, to attract its emanation (e.g., for healing, prediction).
Using auxiliary techniques such as incense burning, prayers directed to stars, invocations, and the use of magic names to enhance the drawing down of spirituality.

Sacrificial rites (e.g., burnt offerings, scapegoat rituals) performed with specific intentions, sometimes directed toward planets (like Mars or Saturn) or the sefirot, to attract beneficial divine/astral influence, avert negative forces, or achieve communion with the divine.
Engraving symbols of emanating stars or constellations onto images or effigies.
Making effigies of specific forms from specific metals at certain times to know the future or exert influence.

Observing Torah commandments and religious practices (e.g., Sabbath, dietary laws, charity, Tabernacle worship) reinterpreted as mechanisms for drawing down or neutralizing astral influences, or for achieving spiritual conjunction.

relevant_quotes.text: [The qualities of the gods and their influences] come from a mixture of plants, stones and spices, Asclepius, that have in them a natural power of divinity. And this is why those gods are entertained with constant sacrifices, with hymns, praises and sweet sounds in tune with heaven’s harmony: so that the heavenly ingredient enticed into idol by constant communication with heaven may gladly endure its long stay among humankind.

What is the basis for The Kuzari’s statement concerning Judaism’s superiority over pagan religions? Judah Halevi is unequivocal on this count: he holds, as noted in the passage quoted above (1:97), that Judaism is superior to religions relying on råhaniyy§t [spirituality], on activities involving talismans, and so forth, because it is more efficient. The worship—the rituals—of the pagan religions resembles the actions of a layman working as a doctor, who uses the medicines in his possession without understanding their purpose, the required dosage, and the circumstances of their administration to the patient. Judaism, however, particularly as it had been known before the exile, abundantly provided and still continues to do so the required information and the ability to deal with issues for which religion ensures the most beneficial support. The utilitarian criterion, then, enables the comparison of which I spoke above, proving Judaism’s superiority. If you will, Judaism is an efficient and useful theurgy, whereas the pagan religions to which Judah Halevi refers are intrinsically unfounded theurgies, because they are far from ensuring any benefits resembling the efficiency and usefulness that Judaism, as a theurgy, provides through its system of commandments.

When doing this, you should say immediately after: I call upon you, the supreme spiritualities, in whom is and from whom comes all human wisdom, to answer me and draw me close to you, and teach me your wisdom, and strengthen me with your power, and let me understand what I do not, and draw me away from events and from the harm caused by distortion or forgetfulness until you bring me to the rung of the greatest ancient sages and soothe my heart, and do not forsake me.

In all magical operations it is indispensable that the stars should be observed. I mean, they [magicians] deem that a certain plant should be assigned to the portion of a certain star; similarly they assign every animal and every mineral to a star. They likewise deem that the operations performed by the magicians are various species of worship offered to a certain star, which, being pleased with that operation or speech or fumigation, does for us what we wish.

In order to keep people away from all magical practices, it has been prohibited to observe any of their [the idolaters’] usages… I mean all that is said to be useful, but is not required by speculation concerning nature, and takes its course, in their opinion, in accordance with occult properties. This is the meaning of its dictum: “And ye shall not walk in the customs [huqqot] of the nation” [Lev. 20:23], these being those that are called by [the sages], may their memory be blessed, ways of the Amorite. For they are branches of magical practices, inasmuch as they are things not required by reasoning concerning nature and lead to magical practices that of necessity seek support in astrological notions. Accordingly the matter is turned into a glorification and a worship of the stars.

The magic-astral model focuses the positive action of the religious precept on drawing down emanation from the world of the sefirot to the terrestrial world through rites prescribed in the Hermetic literature, echoes of which found their way into the worlds of Islam and Judaism. In many cases, the advocates of this model ascribe the descending influence to an additional, astral source (stars, constellations). The religious act is thus directed toward the beneficial, material advantage of the celebrant (the person offering the sacrifice). The magic-astral model is also typified by its mode of operation. The influence is brought down through appropriate preparation on the performer’s part, which involves a certain symbolification of the emanating source.

The Terafim were a human image, made at specific times known to them, and they thought this image would arouse the imaginative faculty so that it would become isolated from the other faculties of the soul to receive supreme power, as was its custom, and hear the likeness of a deep voice that, so they thought, would predict the future.

I believe that the wise men were people who were proficient in Egyptian science, and the essence of that science was to invent the science of sorcery, with which they performed acts that cannot be achieved by natural means. They do so either by sleight of hand, which makes one think that they are doing what they are not doing; or by inventing natural devices that create strange things that look as if they were produced by sorcery; or by performing those strange acts by the method of sorcery, if it prove possible to produce them by sorcery as if they were true acts. And we do not know to this day the essence of that sorcery and its nature, and for that reason we have not seen fit to speak of it.

Therefore there are some who permit the making of some images at certain times depending on the powers of the stars to heal certain sicknesses, commanding that the image of a lion be made during the rule of the sun; of gold, for sickness of the kidneys; and the image of a scorpion for [its] bite; and for epilepsy [?] one makes the image of a fly of copper, to drive away any fly that might come there; and this is no doubt in the category of segullah. Similarly, any image that is not one of the forbidden images, such as the human face if made in relief [three-dimensionally], or the image of a dragon, or the sun, or the moon, or the signs [of the Zodiac], even if not in relief. Perhaps that is permitted if done for medical purposes, for every educated person knows that God granted powers to the stars and to his creatures.

Know that, since the holy pietists reached communion through thought with the supremes, anything they think and intend at that time will come to pass, whether good or bad. It was on this the sages said that “he cast his eyes upon him and he became a heap of bones.” And it was on this matter that the sages said in Ta#anit that “she should return to the dust.” And so the rabbis, of blessed memory, said that “whenever the sages set their eye against one, the result was either death or poverty.” This is the origin of the mystery in prayer and sacrifices, which is the secret of communion with the supremes, and from here comes the accursed power of wicked Balaam...

critical_analysis.relevance: This book offers a critical understanding of the complex, often overlooked, role of astral magic within medieval Jewish intellectual history. It challenges traditional narratives by revealing how Jewish thinkers, despite rabbinic prohibitions and Maimonides' critiques, integrated magical and astrological concepts into their philosophical and theological systems. The book highlights the intellectual sophistication used to legitimize these practices, often cloaked in esoteric language. For scholars of Western Esotericism, it provides invaluable context on how Hermetic and astrological traditions were received, adapted, and debated within a major Abrahamic tradition, offering a nuanced view beyond simple rejection or acceptance.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Academic researchers and scholars in Jewish Studies, Medieval Philosophy, History of Science, Western Esotericism, and Occultism. It is also highly relevant for practitioners interested in the historical and philosophical foundations of Jewish mystical traditions (e.g., Kabbalah) and the broader development of magic in Abrahamic contexts, offering deep insights into the theoretical underpinnings rather than a practical guide.
